instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Clean board overall, had some small corrosion near <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R3203</RESISTOR>, after cleaning the area and reflowing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> same problem, only 5.2v and 0.02a taken.

I then replaced first the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> that was next to the corrosion and same thing, then replaced the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and same thing, those were purchased from Rossmann I sure there are good and both are the C00 ones.

No shorts, but <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> are both 0 volts, I connected the charger in all 4 ways, diode mode to ground on those lines are 0.496 and 0.512.

F30000 and F3010 are both fine.

I also checked redriver and looked fine, but removed it to test anyways but same problem, I am still learning about this USB-C boards and I am having a hard time with them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltages.
Also check <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I had 00840/00875 boards where I got 1.1V LDO output only from one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.
Sometime I did a trick on the port with missing voltage and it worked; but never worked when both chips missed 1.1V LDO.
I suppose you still have a problem with USB-C area; maybe corrosion around <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>/90.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> looks perfect, I checked for shorts and bad resistors around it and found nothing.
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> I tried a different one from a -01 board but no luck.

I just also tried 2 new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and nothing either.

I wonder if [USER="637"]TCRScircuit[/USER] can give us some tips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Put back original <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>; make backup dump first.
Can you see any activity on its pins, with o-scope?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: following.. still havent figured this out either

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have this exact problem.. No solution so far

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: OK, just wanted to let you know i have resolved all of these with a missing BMC LDO by replacing the TBT ROM (<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> on a 00840 board). In all of them, the BMC LDOs came back and i got 20v back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v on both ports, 0v on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_X</SIGNAL>/A/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for mention.
Did you make a backup of working ROM?
Flashing original chip should be sufficient in such case...
